NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cause (sb.) to feel discouraged or disappointed; prevent (sb.) from doing or achieving sth. 使沮丧，使灰心；使受挫折
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The weather frustrated our plans.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. reveal; produce or provide 泄露；产生，提供

NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The GNP of China has increased step by step these years.
e.g. The outcome was not what he had expected.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. happening or developing slowly and by degrees 渐进的，逐步的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There has been a gradual increase in the number of families owning refrigerators.
e.g. Building a car is a long process.
e.g. I found the conclusion of her story very exciting.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. put forward for consideration; suggest 提出，建议
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He proposed that we should go for a walk.
e.g. The research project has only been under way for three months, so it's too early to evaluate its success.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the main or largest part; (largeness of) size 大部分; (巨大的)体积
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The bulk of the work has been done.
e.g. For professional footballers, injuries are an occupational hazard.
e.g. Their school challenged ours to a football match.
e.g. In an invoice（发票）the amount of money should be written both in words and in figures.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (cause to) become smaller, weaker, etc. (使)变小，变少，变弱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We wore down the enemy's resistance.
e.g. Failure is the mother of success.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad. in some way; by some means; for some reason that is not clear 以某种方式；由于某种未弄清的原因
